ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Pre-class videos were released before each class for an overview of what would be explored in class deeper.
None
I also attended office hours.
Pre-class assignments
N/A
We also had preclass videos that would provide an introduction to the material for the next class and handouts that we would use during class.
The course has regular online meeting times, which are intercepted by practice questions and homework in-between.
Recordings for those who miss.
Recorded lecture
along with synchronous lectures, we engages in psets, individual study and office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the importance of asking questions, because even if you feel like you're the only one confused, there will be multiple students with the same question. I also took full advantage of office hours to answer specific questions and build a good relationship with my professor.
I cemented my knowledge in basic calculus.
I learned the fundamentals of single variable calculus.
Differentiation and Integration
Understanding topics instead of just plugging in formulas
I learned basic calculus
Basics of calculus and applications.
Learned calculus skills.
Calc 1 basics
I think that I learned skills, related to mathematical theory; however, I don't think this course effectively taught and evaluated mathematical concepts.
I developed a deeper understanding of calculus.
I learned new ways to approach problems and developed new ways to help lead to an answer.
With the mastery based grading, I learned to stay on top of my weekly assignments and teach myself concepts well to master them.

I understood the basics of derivatives and integrals. Also learned to compute the rate of change of one quantity in terms of another, the rate at which one quantity accumulates  with respect to another, and the relationship between these two ideas
I was able to learn about why certain methods are used that I previously was using but didnt know why.
I developed a better understanding of mathematics within the area of calculus

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Oftentimes we ran out of time in class to go through all the examples related to the newly learned content. It would be great if the professors released an answer key to the notes to allow students to have additional practice with the content.
I think that the mastery system is very amazing.

If you have taken any form of calculus, such as AP Calculus AB, this course is a thorough review of key concepts, along with new ones as well. If you have no background in calculus, and this is your first calculus class, it may be harder to get what's going on in class.
Strengths in content. Weakness in people didn't really know their grade or how they stood in the class
Love the standards based grading.
It could be taught a bit slower so there is more than one class per topic.
Professor Barnes was great and made the course enjoyable. The structure of the course was really good
Strengths - Mastery system provides opportunity to gradually master content without your grade suffering.
A weakness was when I began the problem sets. I should have begun them earlier and had more time to do them.
A lot of stuff to keep track of (hams, psets, quizzes, preclass, etc).

The strengths were the handouts and the professor's level of effort. There are far too many weaknesses to identify. The pre-class videos were ineffective. In the videos, the instructor would cover basic definitions, and then end the video was mathematical theory that was irrelevant to what we were expected to learn. Every day in class (a math class), we wasted 30-40 minutes talking about politics, classroom aesthetics, or Tic-Tok videos. Lastly, one week before reading period, we had 6-week old quizzes that were upgraded.
The main strength of this course was the mastery system. It truly encouraged learning.

The system of grading for this course was something I have never done before. I really like the mastery system as it promotes growth. Especially during covid, the mastery system allowed me to better comprehend the materials.

Due to the online method of the course, office hours were often difficult to utilize if necessary; there were many times where the course's office hours would fall on the same times as other mandatory class meetings. This was largely mitigated by the utilization of the Piazza platform, which allowed questions to be posted for a prompt response by peers, mentors, or the instructor themself. The combination of the two made online learning relatively easy, although without proper ability to use both or a lack of familiarity with it, would make the course difficult to navigate.
Very confusing layout/way of teaching methods.

Strengths: mastery based grading
Weakness: letting students know the standards for grades among those masteries

The strengths of the course was making students solve many problems through problem sets, HAM and quiz. The areas that can be improved are: (1) professor spending more time in the class solving problems rather than putting students in breakout rooms and asking them to solve problems (there was hardly any interaction between students after first few sessions) and (2) either no time limit or a more liberal time limit for quiz, since the objective is to master each content.
I think the course was able to do well virtually because of the use of the white board and jam board.

strength: 
there were lots of readily available office hours to assist with qeustions

weaknesses: 
we seemed to progress through the content extremely quickly in class which at times made it difficult to follow

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Anytime there woud be background noise, the professor would wear headphones to prevent disruption, which helped us stay focused. It was great that the professor had a tablet to work through the problems in front of us. However, it was always difficult to present our own answers to the professor (since the problems were complex and hard to write out on a keyboard). I also would have prefered if more students kept their cameras on, as it made turning my camera on intimidating (but cameras on really help with my engagement).
It was fine. Good as can be.
More dynamic student teacher interaction during class
Live zooms and extra sessions helped.
Sending out videos before class about the topics was great
Online quiz system was really good, but hard to access professor for questions.

I think class could have been more efficient. We often spent too long in the beginning of class going over the beginning of the lesson and the more difficult parts and problems were often not covered.
It was the best you can do for an online math class.
N/A
I think this class did vary well given the circumstances. I cannot think of anything that can be improved.

Professor Barnes always encouraged participation, particularly in the chat and with our breakout room groups. This kept me engaged and the breakout rooms allowed me to actively talk through problems with classmates which also helped learning. We always took a break halfway too which was nice. The only thing that could be improved is probably communication. I feel as though if I needed to ask a question there wasn't any certainly I would hear back in the near future, unless it was in class of course.
No suggestions, zoom is the same for most every class.
the practices were geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic and there is nothing further required
I liked using the jam board as the worksheet that we could follow along with. I think that if we were able to get access to the worksheets before class it wouldve helped even more.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend the course, as it gave me a great foundation for more math courses at Yale. It was challenging, but the professor was always available to ask questions and study groups made the PSETs more enjoyable.
Yes, especially under James Barnes who is amazing.
Unless you've taken calculus before, then no, I wouldn't recommend this class.
Yes... Barnes is one of my favorite teachers Ive ever had.
Yes if they need it for other classes
Yes, solid introduction to basic calculus concepts that are very useful for subjects.
Yes it was not very difficult and the way the course was graded made success rather easy.
Yes, it's a good intro to college math.
No. The course is a risk for a student's overall GPA, due to the inconsistency of grading. The course doesn't teach you concepts, it teaches theory.

I would recommend this course to another student because of the way it is organized. Your understanding of the material is better reflected as opposed to how it would be reflected if there were three major tests.
I would recommend this course because I think it really promotes learning and a safe environment for learning.
I assume most folks taking this course do so as a major prerequisite. That said, it is still one of the courses that are given more resources to assist in going through the course.
If you have to take it then yes.
Yes. Anyone interested in research should take this course as it provides the foundation for calculus
I would recommend the course because it was helpful for me to learn about what I was doing in math.
